pull.title: doc: Add developer note on c_str()
pull.body: Add a note when to use and when not to use `c_str()`.

repo.name: bitcoin
repo.description: Laanwj's Bitcoin Core fork - see README.md on "readme" branch

issue.title: refactor: Change occurences of c_str() used with size() to data()
issue.body:
Using `data()` better communicates the intent here.

~~Also, depending on how `c_str()` is implemented, this fixes undefined behavior: The part of the string after the first NULL character might have undefined contents (or even be inaccessible, worst case).~~ Apparently [this is no longer an issue with C++11](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/17281#discussion_r339742128).

events.message:
doc: Add developer note on c_str()

Add a note when to use and when not to use `c_str()`.

events.body:
ACK 1cf9b35c0dac5f685b7ae62ded16284803816570
I agree that unless you pass a string to C there's almost always a better way to do it in C++. 
(and if you need array I agree with you that `.data()` is more self explanatory)

issue.title: Bitcoin PR tracking
issue.body: The main purpose of this issue is to keep track of Pull Requests on Bitcoin since version 0.19.1 identifying those which make a porting LitecoinZ.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -640,6 +640,29 @@ Strings and formatting
 
   - *Rationale*: Bitcoin Core uses tinyformat, which is type safe. Leave them out to avoid confusion.
 
+- Use `.c_str()` sparingly. Its only valid use is to pass C++ strings to C functions that take NULL-terminated
+  strings.
+
+  - Do not use it when passing a sized array (so along with `.size()`). Use `.data()` instead to get a pointer
+    to the raw data.
+
+    - *Rationale*: This can be dangerous, as the part of the data after the first NULL character is not guaranteed
+    to be initialized at all. Also, `.data()` communicates the intent better.
+
+  - Do not use it when passing strings to `tfm::format`, `strprintf`, `LogPrint[f]`.
+
+    - *Rationale*: This is redundant. Tinyformat handles strings.
+
+  - Do not use it to convert to `QString`. Use `QString::fromStdString()`.
+
+    - *Rationale*: Qt has build-in functionality for converting their string
+      type from/to C++. No need to roll your own.
+
+  - You might want to do extra checking before passing strings that can contain embedded NULL characters, because
comments.body:
Maybe change to:

> - In cases where do you call `.c_str()`, you might want to additionally check that the string does not contain embedded `'\0'` characters[...]

I was initially confused about what this bullet point what referring to after reading the previous three "Do not use it..." points.

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -640,6 +640,29 @@ Strings and formatting
 
   - *Rationale*: Bitcoin Core uses tinyformat, which is type safe. Leave them out to avoid confusion.
 
+- Use `.c_str()` sparingly. Its only valid use is to pass C++ strings to C functions that take NULL-terminated
+  strings.
+
+  - Do not use it when passing a sized array (so along with `.size()`). Use `.data()` instead to get a pointer
+    to the raw data.
+
+    - *Rationale*: This can be dangerous, as the part of the data after the first NULL character is not guaranteed
+    to be initialized at all. Also, `.data()` communicates the intent better.
comments.body:
Is this true after C++11? According to https://en.cppreference.com/w/cpp/string/basic_string/c_str

>  c_str() and data() perform the same function. | (since C++11)

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -640,6 +640,29 @@ Strings and formatting

comments.body: Ok, I didn't know that, I'll remove that from the rationale. But I'd like to keep the suggestion because I still think it's bad form to use `c_str` in these cases.

comments.body: Could say null-terminated instead of NULL-terminated. NULL constant is technically unrelated

comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -640,6 +640,28 @@ Strings and formatting
 
   - *Rationale*: Bitcoin Core uses tinyformat, which is type safe. Leave them out to avoid confusion.
 
+- Use `.c_str()` sparingly. Its only valid use is to pass C++ strings to C functions that take NULL-terminated
comments.body: It's the NULL or NUL character, too. C's NULL constant is indeed unrelated.
